scenarioDescription:
The HR 8799 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HR 8799 is a star with 1.61 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.49 times its radius. It is located 134.52 light years away from the solar system.

HR 8799 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HR 8799 system


HR 8799 b

HR 8799 b was discovered by the Gemini Observatory observatory, in 2008-11, using the imaging method. Its semi-major axis is 68.00 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HR 8799 b is 2226.000 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HR 8799 b is 13.000 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HR 8799 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HR 8799 c

HR 8799 c was discovered by the Gemini Observatory observatory, in 2008-11, using the imaging method. Its semi-major axis is 38.00 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HR 8799 c is 3180.000 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HR 8799 c is 13.000 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HR 8799 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HR 8799 d

HR 8799 d was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2008-11, using the imaging method. Its semi-major axis is 24.00 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HR 8799 d is 3180.000 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HR 8799 d is 13.000 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HR 8799 d is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HR 8799 e

HR 8799 e was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2010-12, using the imaging method. Its semi-major axis is 16.40 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HR 8799 e is 3180.000 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HR 8799 e is 13.115 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HR 8799 e is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HR 8799, which contains 4 exoplanets and was discovered by the Gemini Observatory.
name: HR 8799 - System With 4 Exolanets
